newsitem.title: POLAND: Ameritech blames Polish TPSA over joint venture.
newsitem.headline: Ameritech blames Polish TPSA over joint venture.

text.p: Ameritech Corp accused Polish state-owned telecom firm Telekomunikacja Polska SA (TPSA) of blocking development of their joint PTK Centertel SA mobile phone network, but said it remained committed to the venture.
"Ameritech is -- and always has been -- committed to Centertel," Ameritech International's President Walter Catlow said in a statement issued in Warsaw late on Thursday.
"We hope to continue our strong and successful relationship, despite the unfortunate actions and misunderstandings that have taken place," he added.

But in "background information" issued with the statement from the U.S. firm's Chicago base, Ameritech accused TPSA, which effectively controls Poland's telecommunications, of acting in a way that threatened the future of Centertel.
TPSA spokesman Krzysztof Bartnicki declined comment on Ameritech's statement on Friday, saying he wanted to avoid a row through the media.

In 1991 Ameritech and France Telecom joined state-owned telephone operator TPSA in setting up Centertel as Poland's first nationwide cellular telephone operator, using a dated analog system, which now has 100,000 customers.
They provided all the capital and each had 24.5 percent of the joint venture, with TPSA holding 51 percent.

They invested on an understanding with the then Polish government that they would later get a licence for a GSM digital network, but a tender last year led to licences going to two other groups, which are preparing to start operating.

"Unfortunately, the expansion and future operation of this national asset (Centertel) is in jeopardy due to the denial of the previously-agreed-upon GSM licence and TPSA's opposition to Centertel's expansion into digital telephony," Ameritech said.

"Additionally, TPSA has taken steps that appear to have as their goal either the removal of the foreign partners from the joint venture, or the destruction of the company's business," the notes issued by Ameritech said.
It accused TPSA of blocking approval of Centertel's operating budgets and previously planned capital investments to expand and improve the network to meet its licence obligations.

Ameritech said TPSA had blocked a management change at Centertel and had unilaterally terminated a vital agreement on fees for interconnection to TPSA's ground network, demanding terms under which Centertel could not operate profitably.

The Polish government's Anti-Monopoly Office (UAM) said earlier this week it might launch an action against TPSA over the price it wanted to charge Centertel for connections with the ground telecommunications network.
Bartnicki said talks on renegotiating the agreement on fees were under way, adding: "I have a feeling that the sides will reach agreement."

He said TPSA was not interested in running a mobile phone business itself or taking over Centertel because it did not want to be accused of extending its monopoly. It was committed to keeping Centertel in business, he said.
